Catalyst particle shape is another important parameter for understanding not only the catalytic processes
279− 281 but also the thermodynamic properties of NPs.
204, 261 Differently shaped NPs expose different facets, which can significantly affect the catalyst interactions with adsorbates and reaction intermediates. For example, in studies of CO 2RR over PdH catalysts, Zhu et al. reported significantly higher selectivity toward CO 2 conversion to CO for octahedral NPs (exposing (111) facets) rather than for cubic NPs exposing (100) facets.
282 A change in the NP shape also results in a different number of active low-coordinated sites on the NP surface.
247 On the other hand, different particle shapes can also constitute evidence of different particle–support interactions. For example, the flattened, raft-like shape of Pt NPs on Al 2O 3 and TiO 2 supports can be a signature of strong particle–support interactions.
